com.pump.mac

Class DockIcon

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.mac.DockIcon

  • public class DockIcon
extends java.lang.Object
    This uses reflection to set the dock icon. If you're using Mac 10.5+, this uses the new methods mentioned here: http://developer.apple.com/releasenotes/Java/JavaLeopardUpdate2RN/ResolvedIssues/chapter_3_section_13.html

    Otherwise this tries to use the older Cocoa classes (which are ideal for Mac 10.4-ish).

    Note that the "correct" way to set the dock icon changed once, and it may change again, so I would be reluctant to use this feature as a vital element in my program. (That is: it may fail in coming years.)

    The Cocoa classes are deprecated, but if you have users running 10.4 it's probably the best way to go. You must add "System/Library/Java" to your classpath (either in Eclipse, your app's Info.plist, etc.) for the Cocoa classes to work.

    See Also:
    Dock Icon: Setting the Dock Icon

    • Method Detail

      • isActive

        public static boolean isActive()
        Returns:
        true if this class can modify the dock icon.

      • set

        public static boolean set(java.awt.image.BufferedImage i)
        This tries to reassign the icon of this application in the dock.
        Parameters:
        i - the image to set the dock icon to. If this is null, then the default icon is restored.
        Returns:
        true if it appears this call worked.
